metadata.title: Characterization of dioxymethylene species over cu-zn catalysts

IDRISS, J. P. HINDERMANN, R. KIEFFER, A. KIENNEMANN* Laboratoire de Chimie Organique Appliquee, EHICS, 1, rue Blaise Pascal, 67008 Strasbourg (France) A. VALLET, C. CHAUVIN, J. C. LAVALLEY* Laboratoire de Spectrochimie, ISMRA, 14032 Caen Cedex (France) and P. CHAUMETTE* Institut Francois du Petrole, 1 et 4 av. de Bois-Preau, B. P. 311, 92506 Rueil-Malmaison Cedex (France) (Received October 31, 1986; accepted March 3, 1987) Summary Dioxymethylenic species have been characterized upon adsorption of formaldehyde on zinc aluminate and copper supported on zinc aluminate, by both FTIR spectroscopy and chemical trapping. Dioxymethylene could be an intermediate in the synthesis of methanol on these catalysts in CO + H; and CO; + Hz reactions, as shown by chemical trapping experiments. Introduction In recent years, there have been many attempts to determine the mechanism(s) of methanol synthesis from CO/COz/Hz on Cu/Zn catalysts. Formates [1-6] and formyls [7-9] have often been proposed as reaction intermediates. Kliereta/. [10,11] and Deluzarche et al. [12] have explained the formation of formyi species by direct hydrogenation of formates. Both species have been characterized by different techniques: IR [7, 8], TPD [3] and chemical trapping [13]. On Pd/SiOa, Hindermann et al. [14] have succeeded in characterizing by chemical trapping a third species: adsorbed formaldehyde, which may be formed from formyi species since formates do not exist over these catalysts [15-17]. *Authors to whom correspondence should be addressed. 0304-5102/87/$3.60 Elsevier Sequoia/Printed in The Netherlands 206 H H, H. , H, CH3 ^c=o ?= ^c+o ?==' 6 1 K T l (A) (B) (C) Adsorbed formaldehyde (B) reacts with methanol, dimethyl and diethylsulfates as chemical trapping agent, to give formaldehyde dimethyl or diethylacetal. H ^OCHa X^O + 2CH30H (excess) ?= CH; H ^OCHs (B) (D) Another species, dioxymethylene, may be considered. It was first postulated by Wachs and Madix [18] on Cu(lOO), then by Bowkere^a/. [3] on ZnO, Denise et al. [19] on Cu/ZnO and He and Ekerdt [20, 21] on ZrO;. Recently, Lavalley et al. [22] have characterized this species by IR from formaldehyde adsorption on anatase and thoria, giving characteristic bands at 2960, 2850, 2750, 1112 and 945 cm"1. Onishi et al. [23] observed the same species by IR from reaction of CO/H; over Zr02. The aim of the pres- ent note is to report our observations on Cu/Zn catalysts. The techniques used are chemical trapping and FTIR spectroscopy, and the starting mate- rials are not only CO + H; or CO; + H; but also formaldehyde, formic acid and methanol. Experimental Samples (zinc aluminate, 15% Cu/zinc aluminate and 30% Cu/zinc aluminate were prepared at the Institut Francais du Petrole by the following coprecipitation technique [24]: Precipitation of the metal nitrates (copper, aluminium, zinc) in 0.5 - 1.5 M aqueous solutions is effected with 0.5-1.5 M alkali metal carbonate solution under controlled and constant pH conditions at temperatures between 333 and 363 K. The precipitate is subsequently washed, dried and calcined. All samples were heated under hydrogen flow (2 1 hT1 g~1 cat, 1 C min"1 up to 250 C (523 K) and then further reduced at this temperature, 523 K, during 12 h [14]. 207 Chemical trapping CH^OH, HCOOH, HCHO 25 /xmol of CH30H or HCOOH were introduced into a bulb containing 100 mg of catalyst under ^10~1 Pa. Pressure was then restored to 10s Pa under inert gas (argon) at ambient temperature. The catalyst was then heated to the desired temperature. Trioxane (m.p. 337 K) was introduced in a second bulb connected by a lateral tube to the sample. The entire system was heated to the reaction temperature (380 K) under argon (10s Pa). CO-H^, CO^-H^ The gas mixtures (CO/H; = 1/2 or CO^/Hz = 1/2) were introduced under vacuum until 10s Pa of total pressure was reached. The bulb contain- ing catalyst and synthesis gas was then heated to the desired temperature(s) (see Table 1). Formate, methoxy and dioxymethylene trapping conditions After cooling, the pressure was reduced to ^10~1 Pa. The catalyst amount was divided into three separate parts; each part was kept under inert gas (argon) in a bulb at 105 Pa. An excess of dimethylsulfate was introduced into the first bulb to reveal formates. The bulb was kept at 383 K for 1 h. An excess of ethanol was injected into the second bulb to reveal methoxy. The protonation of the methoxy group was immediate at room temperature. An excess of 1,2-dibromoethane was admitted into the third bulb to reveal dioxymethylene species. The bulb was then heated at 403 K for 75 min. Methyl formate, methanol and dioxolane (products formed after chemical trapping of formates, methoxy and dioxymethylene respectively) were detected by gas chromatography. Reaction yields Formates and methoxy are trapped almost quantitatively within experimental error (about 10%). The lack of a model, for dioxymethylene species trapping, does not allow a quantitative measurement of the reaction yield. However, an estimate can be given by optimization of trapping conditions. Maximum transformation and a good reproducibility were obtained in the conditions given here above. FTIR The samples were examined in the form of disks (0: 16 mm) of 30 mg pressed at 2.108 Pa. The activation was carried out inside an IR cell. The sample was heated to 623 K during 1 h under a flow of air (130 ml min"1). It was kept 2 h at 623 K under air and was then cooled under pure N3 for 30 min. A flow of Ha/N; (10% H;) was then introduced with 208 increasing temperature up to 523 K and the sample kept at 523 K overnight. Then the catalyst was evacuated at 523 K for 15 min and at room temper- ature for 15 min (6 X 10~4 Pa). HCHO was produced from thermal decom- position of trioxane at 420 K. After condensation at the temperature of liquid nitrogen, it was heated at room temperature and then introduced in the IR cell as a vapour phase. Care has been taken to avoid any repolymeriza- tion (P at equilibrium <3.103 Pa). Other adsorbates (HCOOH, C^OH) have also been introduced in gas form. The spectra were recorded on a Nicolet MX-1 FTIR spectrometer. Results Chemical trapping Since both adsorbed formaldehyde and dioxymethylene species are trapped as formaldehyde dimethyl or diethylacetal with methanol or diethyl- sulfate respectively, an ambiguity can arise when both formate and formyi are present [16,17]. Therefore, we used dibromoethane to distinguish between adsorbed formaldehyde and dioxymethylene. "\ ^ ^CH. ^:C. + BrCHaCHaBr > 0' ^-0 0 CHs CH; ^X;4=0 + BrCH2CH2Br -x-^ H H^ ^C^O indicates that formaldehyde is directly adsorbed through both H carbon and oxygen on the metallic sites, l72-H2CO [25]. Chemical trapping results confirmed the existence of dioxymethylene over Ti0 2, ThOz and ZrO; formed from HCHO, as mentioned by Lavalley etal. [22] and Onishie^. [23]. Dioxymethylene species were detected on x% Cu/zinc aluminate, as shown in Table 1, where + means that dioxymethylene species were present, '"*that the concentration was decreasing, and that no dioxymethylene species were detected. Concentrations analyzed from CO/H2, COz/H;, CH30H and HCOOH were in the order of 1CT7 mol g~' cat, while those formed with HCHO were more important (1CT6 mol g~1 cat). The low concentration of dioxymethyl- ene species starting from CO/H;, COz/H;, CH^OH and HCOOH can explain the difference in the detection temperatures. 209 TABLE 1 Evidence of dioxymethylene species at different temperatures (K) Catalyst CO/Hz CO^/Hz HCHO CH30H HCOOH zinc aluminate 380+ 280+ traces 380- 280+ traces 330 15% Cu/zinc aluminate 280+ 300^* 330 280+ 330 380+ 280+ 380- 280+ 330 30% Cu/zinc aluminate 280+ 300 " 330 280+ 330- 380+ 280+ 380- 280+ 330- TABLE 2 Amount of species formed (mol g~1 cat) from trioxane decomposition (10 mg per 0.1 g cat) at 380 K for 1 h Catalyst Formates Methoxy Formates Dioxymethylene Methoxy zinc aluminate 2.09 X 10-3 1.02 X 10-3 2.05 1.1 X10-6 15% Cu/zinc aluminate 1 X 10-3 0.53 X 10-3 1.88 6.5 X10-6 30% Cu/zinc aluminate 1.52 XlO-3 1.04 X 10-3 1.46 0.7 X10-6 As shown below by IR spectroscopy, formaldehyde adsorption from trioxane decomposition leads to dioxymethylene, formate and methoxy species. We report in Table 2 the amount of each species formed, measured by chemical trapping, on the three studied catalysts. Infrared spectroscopy By IR spectroscopy, similar to the cases of ThO;, TiO; etc., dioxy- methylene species have been observed by adsorbing HCHO on the different catalysts. This species forms immediately at room temperature on ZnAl2C>4, and can be characterized by bands at 2885 (br), 2770 (vw), 1265 (vw), 1160, 1130 and 1107 cm"1 (Fig. 1A). They are still present after heating at 323 K but have disappeared after heating at 403 K. At room temperature, adsorp- tion of HCHO on ZnAl204 also gives formate species (1595,1395 and 1370 cm-1). The intensity of the bands increases with time or with increasing 210 1600 1400 1200 1000 Fig. 1. Species formed from adsorption of HCHO 105 JUmol g"1 cat, where M: methoxy; F: formate; D: dioxymethylene; (A) On ZnAl^O^: (1) at room temperature, (2) after 1 h of heating at 323 K, (3) after 1 h heating at 403 K; (B) On 15% Cu/ZnAl204: (1) at room temperature, (2) after 0.5 h at room temperature, (3) after 0.5 h of heating at 323 K. temperature, and at temperatures higher than 323 K, methoxy species (band at 1095 cm"1) become well apparent. On copper catalysts, adsorption of HCHO occurs at room temperature and immediately gives weak bands at 1160 and 1130 cm"1, showing again the formation of dioxymethylene species. Their stability, however, is much less, as they tend to disappear even at room temperature (Fig. 1B). We do not believe that paraformaldehyde can exist in our conditions; Sexton et al. [26] showed that on Cu(llO) paraformaldehyde decomposes to H2CO(g) at T > 230 K. We also observe formate species characterized by the same bands as on ZnAl204, a band at 1355 cm~1 characteristic of copper formate, as well as methoxy species characterized by a band at 1100 cm"! (methoxy on ZnAl204) and a broad band at 1030 cm"1 (methoxy on copper). 211 We therefore conclude that copper increases the reactivity of dioxy- methylene species, giving formate and methoxy species. We have not been able to detect dioxymethylene species from CO + H;, COa + Hz, HCOOH and CHaOH on the studied catalysts. Chemical trapping experiments indicate that this result may be due to low concentration of these species in our conditions. Discussion Recently, Lavalley et al. [22] proposed that the formation of methoxy species from CO/H; on thoria involves dioxymethylene species as interme- diates and a Cannizzaro-type mechanism. In such a mechanism, the ratio HCOO-/CH30- must be equal to one. On our catalysts, this ratio is always greater than one, as shown in Table 2. Therefore an additional oxidation to formates must occur, possibly through the following scheme: H i\ ^" i >C. -H ^C, H2CO + 0(s) > 0 ^0 > 0/^0 11 ! ' \! In the presence of copper, this additional oxidation to formates seems to be less important. It is more difficult to draw a conclusion concerning methoxy formation in the presence or absence of copper because of the possibility of both reactions (Cannizzaro-type and hydrogenation of dioxy- methylene). It seems however that copper plays a role in the transformation of dioxymethylene into methoxy species (as shown by the difference between formate/methoxy ratios, for 15% Cu- and 30% Cu-containing catalysts): CHa ^CH;, H | 0 '0 ?^ 0 ill Bowker et al. [3] and Chan and Griffin [27] have shown that formates are directly formed during the adsorption of methanol without the interme- diate formation of CO or CO;. Table 1 shows further that dioxymethylene species are formed through both CH30H and HCOOH adsorption without the presence of formyi species. We therefore propose that dioxymethylene is an intermediate in the direct oxidation of methanol. We may remark that on copper catalysts, the concentration of dioxy- methylene species formed from CO/H; is about twice as great as that formed 212 from COz + Ha, while the reaction between CO; + H2 leads to more formate species than from CO + Ha (15 and 0.5 X 10~4 mol g~1 cat respectively after 1 h reaction at 403 K). These results indicate a difference in the rate- determining steps in the transformation of CO/Ha and COa/H; respectively. If formate hydrogenation is involved in both processes, CO reaction leads to more active formates than those in the CO-t reaction. This last result is in accordance with that of Chinchen et al. [5], who show that the rate-limiting step in C02/H2 is associated with formate hydrogenation. Conclusion Dioxymethylene species were characterized by chemical trapping starting from CO/H;, C02/H2, formic acid, formaldehyde and methanol, and by PTIR starting from formaldehyde. The difference between the results from chemical trapping and FTIR spectroscopy can be attributed to a higher sensitivity of the chemical trapping, the amounts detected being much smaller starting from CO/H2, C02/H2, formic acid and methanol than from formaldehyde. Our results show that dioxymethylene species are possible interme- diates between formates and methoxy. Copper seems to favour the hydro- genation to methoxy species. However, a concurrent Cannizzaro-type reaction when starting from formaldehyde can disturb these results. Therefore, the hydrogenation of dioxymethylene species to methoxy requires further investigation. coredata.dc:description: Dioxymethylenic species have been characterized upon adsorption of formaldehyde on zinc aluminate and copper supported on zinc aluminate, by both FTIR spectroscopy and chemical trapping. Dioxymethylene could be an intermediate in the synthesis of methanol on these catalysts in CO + H2 and CO2 + H2 reactions, as shown by chemical trapping experiments.
